details.title: A Fast Algorithm for Searching All Multi-State Minimal Cuts
details.standardTitle: A Fast Algorithm for Searching All Multi-State Minimal Cuts

p: Wei-Chang Yeh is currently a Professor of the Department of Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management at National Tsing Hua University in Taiwan. He received his M.S., and Ph.D. from the Department of Industrial Engineering at the University of Texas at Arlington. His research interests include network reliability theory, graph theory, deadlock problem, Linear Programming, and scheduling. He is a member of IEEE, and INFORMS.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Ind. Eng. & Eng. Manage., Nat. Tsing Hua Univ., Hsinchu
authors.name: Wei-Chang Yeh

details.abstract: Evaluating network reliability is an important topic in planning, designing, and control of systems. Many real-world systems are limited-flow (multi-state) networks composed of multi-state components, and their reliabilities can be computed in terms of minimal cut (MC) vectors to level d (named d-MC). A straightforward exact algorithm is presented here. The idea is to find all d-MC prior to calculating the limited-flow network reliability between the source, and the sink nodes (i.e. the one-to-one reliability), under the condition that all MC are known in advance. The proposed method is more efficient and effective compared to the existing algorithms in deleting the duplicate d -MC, verifying d -MC candidates, and finding the lower bounds of edge capacities in d-MC. The concepts of the proposed algorithm are novel, and first developed, followed by the analysis of associated computational complexities. Further, an example is provided to illustrate the generation of all d-MC, and verify that the obtained d-MC are not duplicated.

context.text: Network modeling is employed to validate, verify the designs of, and evaluate the performance of many real-world systems, such as computer and communication systems, power transmission and distribution systems, transportation systems, and oil/gas production systems [1]–[23].
Network reliability evaluation is \$NP\$-hard [1], [2].
However, locating all MC/MP, and evaluating network reliability are both shown to be #P-hard [1]; it is as hard, or even harder than NP-complete problems [1], [2].

Because the number of MC can be as large as \$2^{n-2}\$ [1], we have Hence, the method developed from Theorem 1 is more efficient than the one from Lemma 3 for finding \$L(e)\$ for all \$e\in E\$ [23].

links.abstract: This paper assesses two categories of partition techniques for computing terminal-pair reliability (path-based and cut-based algorithms) by experimenting on published benchmarks; the criteria are the number of subproblems and the computation time. The cut-based algorithm is superior to the path-based algorithm with respect to the computation time for most benchmarks. A refinement of the cut-based algorithm (using network reduction) profoundly outperforms the path-based algorithm (with reduction)...

links.abstract: Many systems can be regarded as flow networks whose arcs have discrete and multi-valued random capacities. The probability of the maximum flow at each various level and the reliability of such a flow network can be calculated in terms of K-lattices which are generated from each subset of the family of all MCs (minimal cutsets). However the size of such a family 2/sup m/-1 (m=number of MCs) grows exponentially with m. Such a flow network can be considered as a multistate system with multistate co...

context.text: Network modeling is employed to validate, verify the designs of, and evaluate the performance of many real-world systems, such as computer and communication systems, power transmission and distribution systems, transportation systems, and oil/gas production systems [1]–[16][23].
A \$d\$-MC is a special MC, but formatted in a system-state vector, where \$d\$ is the lower-bound points of the system capacity level [16]–[23].
The most efficient of the existing methods for evaluating the exact reliability of a flow network with or without unreliable nodes are formulated in terms of \$d\$-MC [16]–[23].
There are several known algorithms in the literature that can be employed to find the duplicated \$d\$-MC between two special nodes [16]–[23].

The time complexity of the related best algorithm for finding all \$d\$-MC is \$O(m^{2}p^{2}\sigma^{2})\$ [16]–[19], [21], [22].
2)Restriction method: A newly generated \$d\$-MC candidate is needed to verify each restriction rule obtained in the current restriction set.
The time complexity of the related best algorithm for finding all \$d\$-MC is \$O(m^{2}p^{2}\sigma^{2})\$ [16]–[19], [21], [22].
From the time complexity discussed above, the proposed algorithm is more efficient than the known algorithms [16]–[23].
In most existing methods [16]–[23], the enumeration of MC and \$d\$-MC involves a computational difficulty which may grow exponentially with the network size.

context.text: Network modeling is employed to validate, verify the designs of, and evaluate the performance of many real-world systems, such as computer and communication systems, power transmission and distribution systems, transportation systems, and oil/gas production systems [1]–[19][23].
A \$d\$-MC is a special MC, but formatted in a system-state vector, where \$d\$ is the lower-bound points of the system capacity level [16]–[19][23].
The most efficient of the existing methods for evaluating the exact reliability of a flow network with or without unreliable nodes are formulated in terms of \$d\$-MC [16]–[19][23].
There are several known algorithms in the literature that can be employed to find the duplicated \$d\$-MC between two special nodes [16]–[19][23].

The time complexity of the related best algorithm for finding all \$d\$-MC is \$O(m^{2}p^{2}\sigma^{2})\$ [16]–[19], [21], [22].
2)Restriction method: A newly generated \$d\$-MC candidate is needed to verify each restriction rule obtained in the current restriction set.
The time complexity of the related best algorithm for finding all \$d\$-MC is \$O(m^{2}p^{2}\sigma^{2})\$ [16]–[19], [21], [22].
Up to now, the best known algorithm for verifying \$d\$-MC candidates in the network was proposed by Yeh [19].
The method of using Lemma 4 to verify general \$d\$-MC candidates is the best of existing methods [19].
From the time complexity discussed above, the proposed algorithm is more efficient than the known algorithms [16]–[19][23].
In most existing methods [16]–[19][23], the enumeration of MC and \$d\$-MC involves a computational difficulty which may grow exponentially with the network size.

context.text: the number of MC, and \$d\$-MC candidates obtained from each MC, respectively [20], [23].

The limited-flow network satisfies the following assumptions [20], [23]:

1)Each node is perfectly reliable.
2)The graph is connected, and free of self-loops.
3)The capacity of each edge, say \$e\$, is a non-negative integer-valued random variable according to a given distribution.
4)The capacities of different edges are \$s\$-independent.
5)All flows in the network obey the conservation law.

Network modeling is employed to validate, verify the designs of, and evaluate the performance of many real-world systems, such as computer and communication systems, power transmission and distribution systems, transportation systems, and oil/gas production systems [1]–[20][23].
A \$d\$-MC is a special MC, but formatted in a system-state vector, where \$d\$ is the lower-bound points of the system capacity level [16]–[20][23].
The most efficient of the existing methods for evaluating the exact reliability of a flow network with or without unreliable nodes are formulated in terms of \$d\$-MC [16]–[20][23].
There are several known algorithms in the literature that can be employed to find the duplicated \$d\$-MC between two special nodes [16]–[20][23].
Note that there is an error in one theorem of [20], as pointed out in [23].

However, this theorem was not applied in Yeh's algorithm in [20], yet it turns out that Yeh's algorithm is still the first, and also the best available restriction method [20].
3)Self-test method: This is a relatively new concept, and it tries to find a criterion for judging whether a newly generated \$d\$-MC (candidate) is a duplicate without comparing it with other \$d\$-MC.
In the algorithms proposed by Yeh in [20], and Yan & Qian in [23], several efforts have been devoted to reduce the number of \$d\$-MC candidates, and remove duplicated \$d\$-MC.
Note that there is an error in one theorem of [20], as pointed out in [23].
However, this theorem was not applied in Yeh's algorithm in [20], yet it turns out that Yeh's algorithm is still the first, and also the best available restriction method [20].
In the algorithms proposed by Yeh in [20], and Yan & Qian in [23], several efforts have been devoted to reduce the number of \$d\$-MC candidates, and remove duplicated \$d\$-MC.
It is extended to networks with unreliable nodes in the implicit algorithm to generate all \$d\$-MC candidates by Yeh in [20].
According to the Restriction Method originally proposed by Yeh [20], the more restriction rules, the fewer associated \$d\$-MC candidates.
The following lemma is the foundation of Yeh's algorithm in [20].
Yan & Qian [23] have recently proposed an algorithm to simplify the method proposed in [20] by finding only the lower capacity bounds before searching for all \$d\$-MC candidates.
From the time complexity discussed above, the proposed algorithm is more efficient than the known algorithms [16]–[20][23].
In most existing methods [16]–[20][23], the enumeration of MC and \$d\$-MC involves a computational difficulty which may grow exponentially with the network size.
Hence, the proposed algorithm is intuitive, simpler, and more efficient than the best of known algorithms [20], [23].
Although we assumed that the nodes in limited-flow networks are perfectly reliable, the proposed algorithm can be modified to effectively accommodate unreliable nodes [20].

links.abstract: This paper presents an efficient cutset approach to compute the reliability of a large communication network having heterogeneous link capacities. The reliability measure has been defined as capacity related reliability (CRR). The proposed method, subset cut technique (SCT), requires the cutset information of the network. For each minimal cut C/sub i/, and a given minimum bandwidth requirement W/sub min/, the method enumerates all nonredundant subset cut (SC), where each SC relates link capaciti...

An efficient cutset approach for evaluating
communication-network reliability with heterogeneous link-capacities
references.text: S. Soh, S. Rai, "An efficient cutset approach for evaluating communication-network reliability with heterogeneous link-capacities", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 54, no. 1, pp. 133-144, 2005.

context.text: Network modeling is employed to validate, verify the designs of, and evaluate the performance of many real-world systems, such as computer and communication systems, power transmission and distribution systems, transportation systems, and oil/gas production systems [1]–[22][23].
A \$d\$-MC is a special MC, but formatted in a system-state vector, where \$d\$ is the lower-bound points of the system capacity level [16]–[22][23].
The most efficient of the existing methods for evaluating the exact reliability of a flow network with or without unreliable nodes are formulated in terms of \$d\$-MC [16]–[22][23].
There are several known algorithms in the literature that can be employed to find the duplicated \$d\$-MC between two special nodes [16]–[22][23].

The time complexity of the related best algorithm for finding all \$d\$-MC is \$O(m^{2}p^{2}\sigma^{2})\$ [16]–[19], [21], [22].
2)Restriction method: A newly generated \$d\$-MC candidate is needed to verify each restriction rule obtained in the current restriction set.
The time complexity of the related best algorithm for finding all \$d\$-MC is \$O(m^{2}p^{2}\sigma^{2})\$ [16]–[19], [21], [22].
From the time complexity discussed above, the proposed algorithm is more efficient than the known algorithms [16]–[22][23].
In most existing methods [16]–[22][23], the enumeration of MC and \$d\$-MC involves a computational difficulty which may grow exponentially with the network size.

references.title:
Evaluate the performance of
a stochastic-flow network with cost attribute in terms of minimal cuts
references.text: Y. K. Lin, "Evaluate the performance of a stochastic-flow network with cost attribute in terms of minimal cuts", Reliability Engineering & System Safety, vol. 91, no. 5, pp. 539-545, May 2006.

context.text: the number of MC, and \$d\$-MC candidates obtained from each MC, respectively [20], [23].

The limited-flow network satisfies the following assumptions [20], [23]:

1)Each node is perfectly reliable.
2)The graph is connected, and free of self-loops.
3)The capacity of each edge, say \$e\$, is a non-negative integer-valued random variable according to a given distribution.
4)The capacities of different edges are \$s\$-independent.
5)All flows in the network obey the conservation law.

Network modeling is employed to validate, verify the designs of, and evaluate the performance of many real-world systems, such as computer and communication systems, power transmission and distribution systems, transportation systems, and oil/gas production systems [1]–[23].
A \$d\$-MC is a special MC, but formatted in a system-state vector, where \$d\$ is the lower-bound points of the system capacity level [16]–[23].
The most efficient of the existing methods for evaluating the exact reliability of a flow network with or without unreliable nodes are formulated in terms of \$d\$-MC [16]–[23].
There are several known algorithms in the literature that can be employed to find the duplicated \$d\$-MC between two special nodes [16]–[23].
Note that there is an error in one theorem of [20], as pointed out in [23].
In the algorithms proposed by Yeh in [20], and Yan & Qian in [23], several efforts have been devoted to reduce the number of \$d\$-MC candidates, and remove duplicated \$d\$-MC.
Note that there is an error in one theorem of [20], as pointed out in [23].
In the algorithms proposed by Yeh in [20], and Yan & Qian in [23], several efforts have been devoted to reduce the number of \$d\$-MC candidates, and remove duplicated \$d\$-MC.
Yan & Qian [23] have recently proposed an algorithm to simplify the method proposed in [20] by finding only the lower capacity bounds before searching for all \$d\$-MC candidates.

Because the number of MC can be as large as \$2^{n-2}\$ [1], we have Hence, the method developed from Theorem 1 is more efficient than the one from Lemma 3 for finding \$L(e)\$ for all \$e\in E\$ [23].
From the time complexity discussed above, the proposed algorithm is more efficient than the known algorithms [16]–[23].
In most existing methods [16]–[23], the enumeration of MC and \$d\$-MC involves a computational difficulty which may grow exponentially with the network size.
Owing to this inherent problem, a moderate sized network discussed in [23] is chosen to demonstrate the methodology.
Hence, the proposed algorithm is intuitive, simpler, and more efficient than the best of known algorithms [20], [23].
